title: Is Plato's cave still pertinent today? - Quora

response.answer_text: Plato’s cave will never not be pertinent. It’s a thought experiment about unfalsifiable claims. So long as our language system will let us make claims that can’t be tested, which is forever, Plato’s Cave will be a useful thought experiment. Plato’s Cave is the earliest formulation of Simulation hypothesis - Wikipedia. It’s what you would imagine if you couldn’t imagine computers yet. By analogy, the walls are the simulation, the fire is computation and ‘us’ is the data. The next step of Plato’s cave, however, is escaping the simulation. This is also useful because it points out an important limit to things we can know. The assertion was we can’t know things that defy our experience up to that point. The new knowledge can destroy our existing knowledge. By extension, finding out our basic assertions were wrong is a dangerous way for humans to feel. We are still humans, so Plato’s Cave is still pertinent.
The real question is: Was is pertinent then? What do you think changed that would make a difference?
